    Disciplines and Integrative Practices

    Professor: John McLevey, PhD
    Department of Knowledge Integration
    Department of Sociology and Legal Studies
    University of Waterloo

    Office: EV1-212
    Office Hours: Every Thursday from 1-3 pm or by appointment
    Email: john.mclevey@uwaterloo.ca or contact me on #slack
    Phone: (519) 888-4567 ext. 31938

    Class Meetings: EV3-4408
    Mondays & Thursdays from 4 - 5:20 pm

    Course Description

    This course introduces students to Knowledge Integration, with a particular focus on the organization of information and knowledge. More specifically, it focuses on how information and expert knowledge are shaped by social networks, information communication technologies, disciplines, and interdisciplinary fields. We will also cover analytic skills that are useful in all types of knowledge work (e.g. managing research collections), and start developing effective research and writing habits.

    Please note that this course emphasizes collaborative learning. Group discussions will usually take place at the beginning of the class, followed by any lecture material at the end. When I lecture, it will mostly be to explain difficult concepts or aspects of the readings that are not addressed in group discussion. Finally, most of the writing you do will be shared with the class using the team collaboration tool #slack.

    Learning Objectives

    By the end of this course, you should be able to:

    • Understand and Apply Course Material
      • Explain how social networks shape information flows, learning, and collective action
      • Describe how “the new media and information ecology” does and does not affect disciplinary and interdisciplinary expert knowledge
      • Characterize the limitations of common-sense thinking for complex problems in the social sciences and humanities
      • Define and explain the importance of “network literacy”
    • Develop Research and Writing Skills
      • Learn fundamental rules of composition
      • Manage research collections using Zotero
      • Start developing good writing habits by writing multiple drafts, and by writing regularly in small amounts

    Assignments & Evaluation

    Given the learning objectives outlined above, your grade in this course will be based on the tasks in Table 1, and described below.

    To do well in this course, you have to take the material seriously, consider it, and discuss it. If you have strongly held opinions, you should be willing to change your mind on the basis of empirical evidence, or rational and respectful argument. That said, you do not have to agree with the readings, with what I say about them, or what others say about them. When you disagree, be respectful.

    TABLE 1: ASSIGNMENTS AND EVALUATION
    Reading Memos (300 words each) Shared on #slack
    1 memo on readings from weeks 1-5 5% night before class
    1 memo on readings from weeks 8-9 5% night before class
    1 memo on readings from weeks 6-7 or 10-11 5% night before class
    Time Diaries (600 words each) Shared on #slack
    1 entry with personal reflection 20% Oct. 16
    1 entry with personal reflection 20% Nov. 13
    Analytic Paper (1,500 words) Shared on #slack
    On "The Future of Networked Individualism" 30% Dec. 5
    Participation / Engagement Shared on #slack
    Involvement in class and on-line conversations 12% ongoing
    Attendance 3% ongoing

    Reading Memos (5% + 5% + 5%)

    You will submit 3 reading memos throughout the semester. You will write a memo on a reading of your choice from weeks 1-5, from weeks 8-9, and from weeks 6-7 or weeks 10-11. Each memo should be roughly 300 words, and should not exceed 330 words. I expect them to be thoughtful, clear, and carefully edited. Your reading memos should identify core points from the readings, offer any thoughts or reactions, and raise possible questions. You are encouraged but not required to relate them to any personal experiences.

    Each memo is due the night before the class where will will discuss the readings you wrote about. These memos will be shared with the class on #slack, where others can read and leave constructive and thoughtful comments. You are not required to comment on the memos, but doing so is a good way to contribute to class discussions. Disrespectful comments will not be tolerated. They will be as damaging to your participation grade as hostile behaviour in the classroom.

    I will grade your reading memos using the following check-minus to check-plus-plus system:

    • Check-Minus: The memo does not engage with the reading, or engages it in a superficial or erroneous way (roughly 0-2/5 or less)
    • Check: The memo reflects on, or poses thoughtful questions about, the reading, and the writing is acceptable (roughly 3/5 or less)
    • Check-Plus: The memo is very insightful, carefully thought through, and well written (roughly 4/5 or less)
    • Check-Plus-Plus: The memo far exceeds my expectations and is very well written (roughly 5/5)

    It is possible to get a check if the ideas in the memo are good but the writing is rough, but you may receive a check-minus if the writing is very poor. Good writing alone will not guarantee that you will get a check-plus or a check-plus-plus.

    Time Diaries with Personal Reflection (20% + 20%)

    You will write two time diary entries on themes from the readings that I announce in class. Following the actual time diary content, you should include a personal reflection that engages class material. Each entry should be roughly 600 words, and should not exceed 650 words. Examples of these time diaries can be found in the “Interlude” sections of the Rainee and Wellman book Networked.

    Like the reading memos, your time diary entries will be shared on #slack for the class to read and leave thoughtful comments on.

    Analytic Paper on “The Future of Networked Individualism” (30%)

    You will write one analytic paper that responds to ideas from “The Future of Networked Individualism” in Rainee and Wellman’s book Networked. The paper should be roughly 1,500 words and should not exceed 1,600 words. I will provide more details about this paper in class.

    Your papers will also be shared on #slack for people to read and leave comments on.

    Participation / Engagement and Attendance (12% + 3%)

    The quality of this course — like any other — depends on you being engaged. Your participation grade will be based on (a) contributions to class discussion, (b) small group discussion, (c) comments left on the course blog, and (d) attendance. If you really don’t like speaking up in class, you can participate more on the course blog.1 Although I will not be assigning a participation grade until the end of the semester, I am happy to provide qualitative feedback on your participation throughout the semester.

    The Writing Centre

    Although I will be giving you feedback on your work throughout the term, I encourage you to make appointments with people at the writing centre. Their services are available to all UW students.

    Submitting Work

    You will submit all work electronically on #slack. Please do not give me hard copies of anything, under any circumstances.

    Late Policy

    I will deduct 5 points a day for every day, or part of a day, that your work is late, including weekends. I will not make exceptions without a medical note.

    Required Books

    • Rainee and Wellman’s Networked: The New Social Operating System. MIT Press.
    • Watt’s Everything is Obvious Once You Know the Answer. Random House.

    These books are available in the university bookstore and on Amazon. They are also available as eBooks in multiple formats. Other readings will be available on LEARN (and in some cases through the library website).

    Recommended Books

    • Tharp’s The Creative Habit. Simon and Schuster.

    LEARN, #slack, and Zotero

    Users can login to LEARN via: http://learn.uwaterloo.ca/. Use your WatIAM / Quest username and password. In addition to LEARN, we will be using the collaboration tool #slack and the reference manager Zotero. I will explain how to use both #slack and Zotero in class.

    Access Ability Services

    The AccessAbility Office, located in Needles Hall, Room 1132, collaborates with all academic departments to arrange appropriate accommodations for students with disabilities without compromising the academic integrity of the curriculum. If you require academic accommodations to lessen the impact of your disability, please register with the AccessAbility Office at the beginning of each academic term.

    Mental Health

    The University of Waterloo, the Faculty of Environment, and our Departments consider students’ well-being to be extremely important. We recognize that throughout the term students may face health challenges — physical and / or emotional. Please note that help is available. Mental health is a serious issue for everyone and can affect your ability to do your best work. Counselling Services2 is an inclusive, non-judgmental, and confidential space for anyone to seek support. They offer confidential counselling for a variety of areas including anxiety, stress management, depression, grief, substance use, sexuality, relationship issues, and much more.

    University Policies

    Academic Integrity

    In order to maintain a culture of academic integrity, members of the University of Waterloo community are expected to promote honesty, trust, fairness, respect and responsibility.3

    We will all uphold academic integrity policies at University of Waterloo, which include but are not limited to promoting academic freedom and a community free from discrimination and harassment. You can educate yourself on these policies — and the disciplinary processes in place to deal with violations — on the Office of Academic Integrity website.

    A student is expected to know what constitutes academic integrity, to avoid committing academic offense, and to take responsibility for his/her actions. A student who is unsure whether an action constitutes an offense, or who needs help in learning how to avoid offenses (e.g., plagiarism, cheating) or about “rules” for group work / collaboration should seek guidance from the course professor, academic advisor, or the Undergraduate Associate Dean. For information on categories of offences and types of penalties, students should refer to Policy 71, Student Discipline.4 For typical penalties, check Guidelines for Assessment of Penalties.5

    Grievances and Appeals

    A student who believes that a decision affecting some aspect of his / her university life has been unfair or unreasonable may have grounds for initiating a grievance. Read Policy 70 — Student Petitions and Grievances, Section 4.6 When in doubt please contact your Undergraduate Advisor for details.

    A decision made or penalty imposed under Policy 70 — Student Petitions and Grievances (other than a petition) or Policy 71 — (Student Discipline) may be appealed if there is a ground. A student who believes he/she has a ground for an appeal should refer to Policy 72 (Student Appeals)7

    Religious Observances

    Student needs to inform the instructor at the beginning of term if special accommodation needs to be made for religious observances that are not otherwise accounted for in the scheduling of classes and assignments.

    Feedback

    I will use LEARN’s Survey tool to solicit brief and informal course evaluations three or four times throughout the semester. These are anonymous, and will only take a few minutes of your time. The purpose is to make sure that we are moving at a comfortable pace, that you feel you understand the material, and that my teaching style is meeting your needs. I will use this ongoing feedback to make adjustments as the course progresses. Although you are not obligated to do so, please fill out the evaluations so that I can make this the best learning experience for you, and the best teaching experience for me.

    Class Schedule and Assigned Readings

    Please note that we may adjust the reading schedule throughout the semester. Changes will be announced in class and via the course website on LEARN.

    Sept. 8 and 11: Introduction & Networked Individualism

    We will get to know each other in the first class. We will start a discussion about “networked individualism” and the “networked operating system” in class on Thursday.

    • MONDAY: First class. No reading.
    • THURSDAY: Start reading Rainee and Wellman Ch. 1 “The New Social Operating System of Networked Individualism”

    Sept. 15 and 18: The Social Network Revolution

    We will begin with a basic introduction to social networks, focusing on recent high-level changes in the structure of our social networks.

    • MONDAY: Finish reading Rainee and Wellman Ch. 1 “The New Social Operating System of Networked Individualism”
    • THURSDAY: Read Rainee and Wellman Ch. 2 “The Social Network Revolution”

    Sept. 22 and 25: The Internet Revolution

    Next, we will discuss the consequences of the Internet, emphasizing how it contributes to the development of an information and knowledge ecology that is distinct from the past.

    • MONDAY: Start reading Rainee and Wellman Ch. 3 “The Internet Revolution”
    • THURSDAY: Finish reading Rainee and Wellman Ch. 3

    Sept. 29 and Oct. 2: The Mobile Revolution

    Next, we will discuss the consequences of mobile phones, and will continue to emphasize the origins of an information and knowledge ecology that is distinct from the past.

    • MONDAY: Start reading Rainee and Wellman Ch. 4 “The Mobile Revolution”
    • THURSDAY: Finish reading Rainee and Wellman Ch. 4

    Oct. 6 and 9: Information & Knowledge

    We will continue to discuss major social changes in how information is organized and accessed. In particular, we will discuss the proliferation of information and how it is increasingly networked. We will discuss how this relates to expert knowledge in disciplinary and interdisciplinary research.

    • MONDAY: Read Rainee and Wellman Ch. 9 “Networked Information”
    • THURSDAY: I will give a lecture on the emergence and institutionalization of academic disciplines. If I decide to assign a specific reading, I will announce it in class a couple of weeks in advance and will make a copy available on LEARN.

    Deadline! If you have not already submitted a reading memo, your first memo is due the night before our Thursday class.

    Oct. 13 and 16: Information & Knowledge Continued

    We will continue our discussion on networked information, but will emphasize the relevance of networked information for the organization of expert knowledge in disciplinary and interdisciplinary research.

    • MONDAY: Holiday. No class.
    • THURSDAY: Read Luker Ch. 5 “Reviewing the Literature”

    Deadline! Your first time diary entry is due before class on October 16.

    Oct. 20 and 23: Writing

    We will read and discuss advice on writing in both academic and non-academic contexts.

    • MONDAY: Read King pages 173-180 and Strunk and White pages 15-33.
    • THURSDAY: Read Silvia Ch. 2 “Specious goals to writing a lot” and Lamott pages 16-27.

    Oct. 27 and 30: Explanations and Problems with Common Sense

    We will begin a conversation about common sense reasoning and complex problems. Our emphasis here will be on the social sciences and humanities.

    • MONDAY: Read Watts Ch. 1 “The Myth of Common Sense”
    • THURSDAY: Read Watts Ch. 2 “Thinking about Thinking”

    Nov. 3 and 6: Success and Fame in Network Context

    We will discuss network explanations for success and fame. This week builds on class discussions about what makes a good explanation.

    • MONDAY: Read Watts Ch 3. “The Wisdom and Madness of Crowds”
    • THURSDAY: Read Watts Ch 4. “Special People”

    Deadline! If you have not already submitted your second reading memo, it is due the night before our Thursday class.

    Nov. 10 and 13: Creativity

    We will read and discuss advice on building good habits for creative work.

    • MONDAY: Read Tharp Ch. 5 “Before you can thinking outside the box, you have to start with a box” and Ch. 6 “Scratching”
    • THURSDAY: Read Tharp Ch. 9 “Skill” and Ch. 12 “The Long Run”

    Deadline! Your second time diary entry is due before class on November 13.

    Nov. 17 and 20: Revisiting Networked Individualism

    Next, we will discuss Rainee and Wellman’s arguments about “thriving” as networked individuals. Topics will include network literacy, diversifying networks, and having diverse sources of information.

    • MONDAY: Start reading Rainee and Wellman Ch. 10 “Thriving as a Networked Individual”
    • THURSDAY: Finish reading Rainee and Wellman Ch. 10 “Thriving as a Networked Individual”

    Deadline! If you did not submit a reading memo in Weeks 6, 7, or 10, it is due the night before our Thursday class.

    Nov. 24 and 27: The Future of Networked Individualism

    We will read and debate the final, more speculative, chapter on the future of networked individualism.

    • MONDAY: Start reading Rainee and Wellman Ch. 11 “The Future of Networked Individualism”
    • THURSDAY: Finish reading Rainee and Wellman Ch. 11 “The Future of Networked Individualism”

    Dec. 1: Debriefing

    Finally, we will debrief on the course overall. This will include a class conversation about what worked, what didn’t work so well, and what could be improved on for next year.

    • MONDAY: No reading.
